thread.title: Is this Queensland's hardest working lifesaving volunteer?
thread.title_full: Is this Queensland's hardest working lifesaving volunteer?

author: Thomas Forbes
title: Is this Queensland's hardest working lifesaving volunteer?
text:
You are in trouble in the Gold Coast surf and put up your arm to call for a lifesaver, when the man who comes to your rescue is old enough to be your grandfather. 
Fear not — you are in safe hands. 
One of Queensland's hardest working Surf Life Saving volunteers, Peter Anderson, has just turned 80. 
He spends about 500 hours a year volunteering in the red and yellow on the Gold Coast and insists he has no intention of slowing down. 
With lives on the line, Mr Anderson is no different from any other lifesaver and must pass a series of mental and physical tests every year to ensure his proficiency. 
Last month, he celebrated his milestone birthday while travelling through Europe. 
But within hours of returning home he said he was back on the beach. 
"For me it's been the absolute highlight of my life, it truly has been," he said. 
"I consider it a privilege and pleasure to do what I do." 
The octogenarian covers the dawn patrol three mornings a week with longtime patrol partner Grahame Long. 
They begin their shift at 4:30am and cover a 16-kilometre stretch of beach from Miami to the Southport Spit until the professional lifeguards begin at 8:00am. Photo: Mr Anderson with paramedics performing CPR. (Supplied: Peter Anderson) 
Mr Long said working with Mr Anderson for the past eight years had been truly rewarding. 
"I look at him sometimes and you've got to actually shake yourself and say, 'hang on, here's this guy, 80, and he's still out here of a morning'," he said. 
"He still rides jet skis, he still does a kilometre swim and them he'll go to gym." 
Mr Anderson joined the movement 20 years ago and is a patrol captain at the iconic Surfers Paradise Surf Life Saving club. 
"It's certainly been interesting over the years. A lot of things have happened on Surfers Paradise beach, but fortunately we've never lost anybody that's been swimming in the flags," he said. 
Mr Anderson's wife of 33 years, Persis, said he threw himself into his business career and transferred that work ethic to surf lifesaving after he retired. Photo: Mr Anderson patrolling Surfers Paradise beach. (Supplied: Peter Anderson) 
"Look I'm really, really not just happy, but very proud of what he does and what he has achieved and lifesaving has given him a new lease on life," she said. 
Gold Coast Lifesaving services coordinator Nathan Fife said Mr Anderson had to undertake a series of annual physical and mental tests to ensure he remained fit for the job. 
"So Pete's got to do a 200-metre swim, a 200m beach run, a board tube rescue and also there's CPR and resus[citation] in that as well," he said. 
"Also, an online theory paper for changes during the year — and that's every year that that has got to be done." 
Mr Anderson said he had no plans to hang up his surf cap. 
"Eighty for me is not the end. While I can still be proficient, and while still valuable, and while Persis is still tolerant, I'll go as long as I can," he declared.
